item.title: Science homework
item.dc:creator: @Man_UTD_Freak Man UTD Freak
item.description:
@Man_UTD_Freak wrote:

bootnecklad:

I think this is the experiment where you heat copper carbonate, while its heating it realeases carbon dioxide and it looks like its “boiling” the reason its black is because its oxidised (sp i think)

In that case, the light green powder being Copper Carbonate is a compound considering you’re right and it is Copper Carbonate after all.

For your reasoning you could write down the properties of Copper Carbonate and what occurs when Copper Carbonate is heated in a test tube, which gas is given off when Copper Carbonate is heated and when heated, the fact that Copper Carbonate becomes black. All of this is just to prove the point that the light green powder is Copper Carbonate.

I think the light green powder is Copper Carbonate as you can see on the picture on Wikipedia.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copper(II)_carbonate

I see that you’ve also posted the question on Wiki Answers.

http://wiki.answers.com/Q/If_a_light_green_powder_is_heated_in_a_test_tube_A_gas_is_given_off_while_the_solid_becomes_black_In_which_classification_of_matter_does_the_green_powder_belong

Read full topic

item.title: Science homework
item.dc:creator: @dontaskmemyname dontaskmemyname
item.description:
@dontaskmemyname wrote:

Can’t figure out this question ;~;

A light green powder is heated in a test tube. A gas is given off, while the solid becomes black. In which classification of matter does the green powder belong? Explain your reasoning.

and FYI: The only classifications of matter we’ve learned are compounds, elements, and mixtures -> (solutions, suspensions, and colloids). So it’s probably one of those choices.

Read full topic
